keywords.long_help: The 'var' keyword is used to declare a new variable. Variables can hold values of any data type including strings, numbers, booleans, JSON objects, and arrays.
The 'print' keyword outputs the given value or expression to the console. It automatically converts values to strings for display.
The 'call' keyword is used to invoke builtin functions. It can be used as a statement or within expressions to execute system-provided functionality.
keywords.example:
var content = call file.readTextFile(path="data.txt");
call debug.log(message="Processing started");

keywords.short_description: Returns a value from a block
keywords.long_help: The 'return' keyword exits the current execution block and optionally returns a value. It's commonly used in functions and conditional blocks.
The 'if' keyword begins a conditional statement that executes code based on a boolean condition. Must be followed by 'then' and optionally 'else'.
The 'then' keyword follows an 'if' condition and introduces the block of code to execute when the condition is true.
The 'else' keyword provides an alternative execution path when the 'if' condition evaluates to false.
The 'foreach' keyword creates a loop that iterates over each element in a collection (array or JSON array). Must be used with 'in'.
The 'in' keyword is used in 'foreach' loops to specify the collection to iterate over.
The 'while' keyword creates a loop that continues executing as long as the specified condition remains true. Must be followed by 'do'.
The 'do' keyword introduces the body of a 'while' or 'foreach' loop, marking the start of the code block to be executed repeatedly.
The 'break' keyword (also 'exit') immediately exits the current loop, continuing execution after the loop block.
The 'continue' keyword skips the remaining code in the current loop iteration and proceeds to the next iteration.
The 'connect' keyword creates a new database connection using a JDBC connection string. Supports Oracle, MySQL, and PostgreSQL.
keywords.example:
connect db = "jdbc:oracle:thin:@//host:1521/service";
connect mysqlDb = "jdbc:mysql://localhost:3306/mydb";

keywords.long_help: The 'use' keyword creates a context block for database operations, automatically managing connection resources.
The 'cursor' keyword declares a database cursor for iterating through query results. Cursors must be opened, used, and then closed.
The 'open' keyword executes a cursor query with optional bind parameters, preparing it for iteration.
keywords.example: open c(id: 123, status: "active");

keywords.long_help: The 'close' keyword releases resources associated with a cursor or database connection.
keywords.example:
close c;
close connection db;

keywords.long_help: The 'connection' keyword is used with 'close' to explicitly close a database connection.
keywords.example: close connection db;

keywords.long_help: The 'select' keyword begins a SQL query to retrieve data from database tables.
keywords.example: cursor c = select * from users where age > 18;

keywords.long_help: The 'from' keyword in SQL queries specifies which table or tables to query data from.
keywords.example: select name, email from customers;

keywords.long_help: The 'where' keyword in SQL queries specifies conditions for filtering results.
keywords.example: select * from orders where status = 'pending';

keywords.long_help: The 'order' keyword in SQL queries sorts the results. Must be followed by 'by' and column name(s).
keywords.example: select * from products order by price;

keywords.long_help: The 'by' keyword follows 'order' or 'group' in SQL queries to specify the column(s) to use.
keywords.example: select * from items order by created_date by desc;

keywords.long_help: The 'group' keyword in SQL queries groups rows that have the same values in specified columns.
keywords.example: select department, count(*) from employees group by department;

keywords.long_help: The 'having' keyword filters results after grouping, similar to 'where' but for aggregated data.
keywords.example: select dept, count(*) from emp group by dept having count(*) > 5;

keywords.long_help: The 'null' keyword represents the absence of a value or an uninitialized variable.
The 'true' keyword represents the boolean true value.
The 'false' keyword represents the boolean false value.

builtins.long_help: Reads the entire contents of a text file and returns it as a string. The file must be in a safe directory or the script's own directory.
builtins.example:
var content = call file.readTextFile(path="data.txt");
print content;

builtins.long_help: Writes the given text content to a file. Creates the file if it doesn't exist, overwrites if it does. The file must be in a safe directory.
builtins.example: var success = call file.writeTextFile(path="output.txt", content="Hello, World!");

builtins.long_help: Appends the given text content to the end of an existing file. Creates the file if it doesn't exist.
builtins.example: call file.appendTextFile(path="log.txt", content="New log entry\n");

builtins.long_help: Returns true if the specified file or directory exists, false otherwise.
Deletes the specified file. Returns true if successful, false if the file doesn't exist or couldn't be deleted.
builtins.example: var deleted = call file.delete(path="temp.txt");

builtins.long_help: Returns a JSON array containing the names of files and subdirectories in the specified directory.
Converts any value to its string representation.
builtins.example:
var num = 42;
var str = call string.toString(value=num);

builtins.long_help: Returns a new string with all characters converted to uppercase.
builtins.example:
var upper = call string.toUpper(str="hello");
print upper; // "HELLO"

builtins.long_help: Returns a new string with all characters converted to lowercase.
builtins.example:
var lower = call string.toLower(str="WORLD");
print lower; // "world"

builtins.long_help: Returns a new string with leading and trailing whitespace removed.
builtins.example:
var trimmed = call string.trim(str="  hello  ");
print trimmed; // "hello"

builtins.long_help: Returns a new string with all occurrences of the target substring replaced with the replacement string.
builtins.example:
var result = call string.replace(source="hello world", target="world", replacement="there");
print result; // "hello there"

builtins.long_help: Splits a string into an array of substrings using the specified regex pattern as the delimiter. Returns a JSON array.
Concatenates all elements of a JSON array into a single string, separated by the specified delimiter.
Returns true if the string contains the specified substring, false otherwise.

builtins.short_description: Checks if string starts with prefix
builtins.long_help: Returns true if the string starts with the specified prefix, false otherwise.

builtins.short_description: Checks if string ends with suffix
builtins.long_help: Returns true if the string ends with the specified suffix, false otherwise.
Returns a substring of the original string, starting at the specified index and optionally ending at another index.
builtins.example:
var sub = call string.substring(str="hello world", startIndex=0, endIndex=5);
print sub; // "hello"

builtins.long_help: Returns the number of characters in the string.
builtins.example:
var len = call string.length(str="hello");
print len; // 5

builtins.long_help: Parses a JSON-formatted string and returns it as a JSON object (Map or List).
builtins.example:
var obj = call json.jsonFromString(jsonString="{\"name\":\"Alice\",\"age\":30}");
print obj.name;

builtins.long_help: Retrieves a value from a JSON object using a dot-notation path. Returns null if the path doesn't exist.
builtins.example: var value = call json.get(root=myJson, path="user.address.city");

builtins.long_help: Retrieves a string value from a JSON object using a dot-notation path. Returns a default value if the path doesn't exist.
builtins.example: var name = call json.getString(root=config, path="database.host", default="localhost");

builtins.long_help: Retrieves an integer value from a JSON object using a dot-notation path. Returns a default value if the path doesn't exist.
builtins.example: var port = call json.getInt(root=config, path="server.port", default=8080);

builtins.long_help: Retrieves a boolean value from a JSON object using a dot-notation path. Returns a default value if the path doesn't exist.
builtins.example: var enabled = call json.getBool(root=config, path="features.logging", default=false);

builtins.long_help: Sets a value at the specified path in a JSON object. Creates intermediate objects as needed. Returns the modified JSON object.
builtins.example: var updated = call json.set(root=myJson, path="user.name", value="Bob");

builtins.long_help: Removes the value at the specified path from a JSON object. Returns the modified JSON object.
builtins.example: var updated = call json.remove(root=myJson, path="user.tempData");

builtins.long_help: Returns true if the JSON object or array is empty (no properties or elements), false otherwise.
Registers a JSON schema with a given name for later validation. The schema defines the expected structure, types, and constraints for JSON data.
builtins.example:
var schema = {"type": "object", "properties": {"name": {"type": "string"}}};
call json.registerScheme(name="personSchema", schema=schema);

builtins.long_help: Analyzes a JSON object and generates a schema that describes its structure. Optionally calculates length constraints for strings and arrays.
builtins.example:
var data = {"name": "Alice", "age": 30};
var schema = call json.deriveScheme(json=data, calcLengths=false);

builtins.long_help: Validates a JSON object against a registered schema. Returns a list of validation errors, or an empty list if validation succeeds.
Creates a new array with the specified size. Elements are initialized to null or zero depending on type.
builtins.example: var arr = call array.create(size=10, type="int");

builtins.long_help: Returns the number of elements in the array.
builtins.example:
var len = call array.length(array=myArray);
print len;

builtins.long_help: Returns the element at the specified index in the array. Throws an error if the index is out of bounds.
builtins.example: var item = call array.get(array=myArray, index=0);

builtins.long_help: Sets the value at the specified index in the array. Throws an error if the index is out of bounds.
builtins.example: call array.set(array=myArray, index=0, value="Hello");

builtins.long_help: Returns true if the array contains the specified value, false otherwise.
Returns the index of the first occurrence of the specified value in the array, or -1 if not found.
builtins.example: var pos = call array.indexOf(array=items, value="apple");

builtins.long_help: Sorts the elements of the array in place. For ascending order, use ascending=true.
builtins.example: call array.sort(array=numbers, ascending=true);

builtins.long_help: Returns the absolute value of the specified number.
builtins.example:
var result = call math.abs(value=-5.5);
print result; // 5.5

builtins.long_help: Rounds the specified number to the nearest integer value.
builtins.example:
var rounded = call math.round(value=3.7);
print rounded; // 4

builtins.long_help: Rounds the specified number down to the nearest integer (towards negative infinity).
builtins.example:
var floored = call math.floor(value=3.9);
print floored; // 3

builtins.long_help: Rounds the specified number up to the nearest integer (towards positive infinity).
builtins.example:
var ceiled = call math.ceil(value=3.1);
print ceiled; // 4

builtins.long_help: Returns the value of the base raised to the specified exponent (base^exponent).
builtins.example:
var result = call math.pow(base=2.0, exponent=3.0);
print result; // 8.0

builtins.long_help: Returns the square root of the specified number.
builtins.example:
var result = call math.sqrt(value=16.0);
print result; // 4.0

builtins.long_help: Returns the smaller of two numeric values.
builtins.example:
var min = call math.min(a=5.0, b=3.0);
print min; // 3.0

builtins.long_help: Returns the larger of two numeric values.
builtins.example:
var max = call math.max(a=5.0, b=3.0);
print max; // 5.0

builtins.long_help: Returns a random double value between 0.0 (inclusive) and 1.0 (exclusive).
builtins.example:
var rand = call math.random();
print rand;

builtins.long_help: Outputs a debug message to the debug console if debugging is enabled.
builtins.example: call debug.log(message="Processing started");

builtins.long_help: Enables debug mode, causing debug.log messages to be output.
builtins.example: call debug.on();

builtins.long_help: Disables debug mode, suppressing debug.log messages.
builtins.example: call debug.off();

builtins.long_help: Throws an error if the specified condition is false. Used for debugging and testing.
builtins.example: call debug.assert(condition=(x > 0), message="x must be positive");

builtins.long_help: Returns a JSON object containing all currently defined variables and their values.
builtins.example:
var allVars = call debug.vars();
print allVars;

builtins.long_help: Returns the value of the specified environment variable, or a default value if not found.
builtins.example: var home = call system.getEnv(name="HOME", default="/home/user");

builtins.long_help: Executes a system command and returns the output. The working directory can be optionally specified.
builtins.example:
var output = call system.exec(command="ls -la", cwd="/tmp");
print output;

builtins.long_help: Pauses script execution for the specified number of milliseconds.
builtins.example: call system.sleep(millis=1000); // Sleep for 1 second

builtins.long_help: Returns the current date and time as a Date object.
builtins.example:
var now = call date.now();
print now;

builtins.long_help: Formats a date object as a string using the specified format pattern (Java SimpleDateFormat syntax).
builtins.example: var formatted = call date.format(date=myDate, format="yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss");

builtins.long_help: Parses a date string using the specified format pattern and returns a Date object.
builtins.example: var parsed = call date.parse(dateString="2024-01-15", format="yyyy-MM-dd");

builtins.long_help: Executes an HTTP GET request to the specified URL. Returns a JSON envelope containing status, headers, and body. Optional headers can be provided as a JSON object. Timeout is in milliseconds.
builtins.example:
var response = call http.get(url="https://api.example.com/data", headers={"Authorization": "Bearer token"}, timeoutMs=5000);
print response.status;

builtins.long_help: Executes an HTTP POST request with optional body content. Returns a JSON envelope with status, headers, and body. Headers are optional JSON object. Body is sent as-is.
builtins.example: var response = call http.post(url="https://api.example.com/submit", body="{\"key\": \"value\"}", headers={"Content-Type": "application/json"});

builtins.long_help: Performs HTTP GET and automatically parses the response body as JSON. Throws an error if response is not valid JSON. Returns the parsed JSON directly (not wrapped in envelope).
Performs HTTP POST with JSON body and parses the JSON response. Automatically serializes the jsonBody parameter and sets Content-Type header. Returns parsed JSON response.
builtins.example:
var payload = {"username": "alice", "email": "alice@example.com"};
var result = call http.postJson(url="https://api.example.com/users", jsonBody=payload);

builtins.long_help: Performs HTTP GET and returns the response body as a plain string. Useful for fetching HTML, XML, or plain text content.
builtins.example:
var html = call http.getText(url="https://example.com");
print html;

builtins.long_help: Performs HTTP POST with text body and returns response as plain string. The body parameter is sent as-is without JSON serialization.
builtins.example:
var xmlData = "<request><id>123</id></request>";
var response = call http.postText(url="https://api.example.com/process", body=xmlData, headers={"Content-Type": "application/xml"});

builtins.long_help: Checks if an HTTP response has a 2xx status code. Accepts either a full response envelope or just a status code. Throws an error with optional message if status is not 2xx.
builtins.example:
var response = call http.get(url="https://api.example.com/data");
call http.ensure2xx(statusOrEnvelope=response, message="Failed to fetch data");

builtins.long_help: Calls an OpenAI-compatible API to generate text completions. Supports optional system prompt, required user prompt, and optional maxTokens and temperature parameters. Uses configuration from system properties or environment variables.
builtins.example:
var answer = call ai.complete(system="You are a helpful assistant", user="Explain quantum computing", maxTokens=500, temperature=0.7);
print answer;

builtins.long_help: Uses AI to generate a concise summary of the provided text. Optionally specify maximum tokens for the summary length.

Generates vector embeddings for the given text using an AI embedding model. Returns a JSON array of floating-point numbers representing the semantic meaning of the text. Useful for similarity searches and semantic analysis.
builtins.example:
var embedding = call ai.embed(text="machine learning");
print "Embedding dimension: " + call array.length(array=embedding);

builtins.long_help: Uses AI to classify the given text into one of the provided labels. The labels parameter should be a JSON array of strings. Returns the most appropriate label.
